title: How to solve the given differential equation xy' + y = y^(2) log(x) - Quora

response.answer_text: This is a Bernoulli equation of the form: [math]\frac{dy}{dx} + p(x)\,y = q(x)\,y^n[/math].We can solve by using the substitution: [math]v = y^{1-n}[/math], which will give equation: [math]\begin{array}{c} \dfrac{dv}{dx} + (1\!-\!n)p(x)\,v = (1\!-\!n) q(x)\end{array}[/math]  Rewrite Bernoulli Equation in the appropriate form: [math]xy’ + y = y^2\ln x[/math] [math]\dfrac{dy}{dx} + \dfrac{1}{x}\:y = \dfrac{\ln x}{x}\:y^2[/math] Use a substitution: [math]v = y^{1-2} = y^{-1}[/math] [math]\begin{align*} \frac{dv}{dx} & = -y^{-2}\,\frac{dy}{dx} \\ & = -y^{-2} \left( -\frac{1}{x}\:y + \frac{\ln x}{x}\:y^2 \right) \\ & = \frac{1}{x}\:y^{-1} - \frac{\ln x}{x} \\ & = \frac{1}{x}\:v - \frac{\ln x}{x} \end{align*}[/math] [math]\dfrac{dv}{dx} - \dfrac{1}{x}\:v = -\dfrac{\ln x}{x}[/math] Find integrating factor: [math]\mu = e^{\int -\frac{1}{x}\,dx} = e^{-\ln x} = \dfrac{1}{x}[/math] [math]\dfrac{1}{x}\,\dfrac{dv}{dx} - \dfrac{1}{x^2}\:v = -\dfrac{\ln x}{x^2}[/math] Solve for v: [math]\dfrac{d}{dx} \left(\dfrac{v}{x}\right) = -\dfrac{\ln x}{x^2}[/math] [math]d \left(\dfrac{v}{x}\right) = -\dfrac{\ln x}{x^2} \: dx[/math] Integrate by parts: [math]\begin{array}{ll} \begin{align*}  \frac{v}{x} & = \int -\frac{\ln x}{x^2} \: dx \\ & = \frac{1}{x}\ln x - \int \frac{1}{x^2} \:dx \\ & = \frac{1}{x}\ln x + \frac{1}{x} + C \\ v & = Cx + \ln x + 1 \end{align*}  & \left\{ \begin{array} {l} \int u\:dw = uw - \int w\:du \\ \begin{array} {ll} u = \ln x & dw = -\frac{1}{x^2} \: dx \\ du = \frac{1}{x}\:dx & w = \frac{1}{x} \end{array} \end{array}  \right. \end{array}[/math] Substitute back and solve for y: [math]y^{-1} = Cx + \ln x + 1[/math] [math]\boxed{\boldsymbol{y = \frac{1}{Cx + \ln x + 1}}}[/math]
You differentiate implicitly, y+xdy/dx+dy/dx=2ydy/dx×1/x Rearranging -xdy/dx-dy/dx+2ydy/xdx=y Factorising dy/dx dy/dx=y/(-x-1+2y/x) I think its clear!!!
